text: Different types of acute myeloid leukemia blast cells were induced to differentiate in vitro with all-trans-retinoic acid ( ATRA ) and vitamin D3 ( VD ) .
M0 / M1 leukemic cells are not sensitive to differentiating agents , whereas M3 leukemic cells are induced to undergo granulocytic differentiation after ATRA treatment but are not sensitive to VD .
M2 leukemic blast cells behave differently because they undergo monocytic differentiation with both the differentiation inducers .

To gain some insight into the maturation of M2-type leukemic cells , we studied the molecular mechanisms underlying monocytic differentiation induced by ATRA and VD in spontaneous M2 blast cells as well as in Kasumi-1 cells ( an acute myeloid leukemia M2-type cell line ) .

Our results indicate that ATRA as well as VD efficiently increases the nuclear abundance of <extra_id_0> VD receptor <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ( <extra_id_0> VDR <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ) and promotes monocytic differentiation .

text: <extra_id_0> VDR <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> is functionally active in ATRA - treated Kasumi-1 cells because it efficiently heterodimerizes with <extra_id_0> retinoid X receptor <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , binds to a DR3-type vitamin D - responsive element , and activates the transcription of a vitamin D - responsive element - regulated reporter gene .

text: Consistent with these findings , VD - responsive genes are induced by ATRA treatment of Kasumi-1 cells , suggesting that the genetic program underlying monocytic differentiation is activated .

The molecular mechanism by which ATRA increases the nuclear abundance of a functional <extra_id_0> VDR <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> is still unknown , but our data clearly indicate that the M2 leukemic cell context is only permissive of monocytic differentiation .
